fields.Title of Contribution: Situating the Voice of the Other in W.S. Merwin's Folding Cliffs
fields.Description/Abstract:
W. S. Merwin’s 1998 volume The Folding Cliffs is a book-length narrative poem about the famous nineteenth-century Kauaians Pi‘ilani and her husband Ko‘olau.  The poem tells how the couple kept their family intact by preventing the exile of Ko‘olau and the couple’s son Kaleimanu to the leper colony on the remote island of Moloka‘i.  Merwin characterizes Pi‘ilani as the protagonist, partly by beginning his narrative after the deaths of the husband and son and focusing on Pi‘ilani’s memory of them, then circling back to present their story more fully.  Toward the end of The Folding Cliffs, moreover, Merwin describes Pi‘ilani’s dictation of her story about her son and husband’s last days to the journalist John Sheldon.  While this part of Merwin’s narrative poem records Sheldon’s documentation and revision of Pi‘ilani’s story about her husband’s leprosy and death, it also echoes and differs from Merwin’s own account of Ko‘olau’s last days, a story Merwin dramatizes in the preceding pages of his poem.  In this self-reflexive scene of writing, Merwin invites his readers to speculate upon the similarities and differences between his poetic account of Pi‘ilani’s story and Sheldon’s version of it.  Beyond that, this narrative doubling reveals Merwin’s awareness that his writing risks violating the integrity of Pi‘ilani’s experience just as much as Sheldon’s does.  While Merwin accepts the impossibility of telling Pi‘ilani’s story more accurately than Sheldon did, he also forces his readers to recognize the autonomy of Pi‘ilani and her family by repeatedly expressing her sense that her story differs from Sheldon’s expectations about it.  Paradoxically, Merwin’s readers experience Pi‘ilani most vividly through her sense of difference, but that difference also guarantees that she remains “other” to the reader.  
By portraying Pi‘ilani’s dictation of her story to John Sheldon, Merwin makes his readers keenly aware of Gayatri Chakravorty Spivak’s claim that “All speaking, even seemingly the most immediate, entails a distanced decipherment by another, which is, at best, an interception” (309).   In focusing on the issues of “decipherment” and “interception” as she tells her story, Merwin underscores the irony and personal compromise of  Pi‘ilani’s predicament.  As a “native informant” (to use Spivak’s phrase), Pi‘ilani experiences the alienation entailed in the “interception” of her story by Sheldon.  Since Pi‘ilani learns to read and write in The Folding Cliffs, Merwin implies that she could have written her own story instead of reporting it to Sheldon (though she would presumably have encountered difficulty in publishing it by herself).  Merwin lets his readers see Sheldon’s sympathy at work as he records Pi‘ilani’s story, but he also invites them to recognize how Sheldon’s assumptions and concerns as a writer frame, and even skew, Pi‘ilani’s experience.  At the same time, Merwin allows his readers to recognize his own dependency on Sheldon’s narrative for important details of Pi‘ilani’s story (a dependency he admits to when he describes his experience of reading Frances N. Frazier’s translation of Sheldon’s book in “How I Came to Write The Folding Cliffs”). In doing so, he invites his readers to honor  Pi‘ilani as the source of her story, recognizing that because he offers only a version of it, they can admire its protagonist and sympathize with her without presuming to know or possess her story in a definitive (and hence totalizing) way.
